para.emphasis: The Life and Work of J.D. Salinger

passage.para: Writer J. D. Salinger will always be remembered for his most famous character, Holden Caulfield. The protagonist of the novel The Catcher in the Rye, Caulfield became the voice of disaffected youth not only for his generation-those coming of age in the early 1950s-but for generations to come. The struggle to reconcile innocence and youth with the pressures and expectations of the wider world is a theme that runs not only through Salinger's work, but his life as well.

Jerome David Salinger was born in New York City in 1919 to an upper-middle class family. His father was a manager in a successful cheese and meat importing company. As an adolescent, Salinger attended public schools as well as a military academy. He dropped out of several colleges in New York, opting instead to immerse himself in the Greenwich Village literary scene. This route paid off for Salinger; he had his first work published in 1940 in Story magazine, after making the acquaintance of some of New York's most prestigious editors.

Salinger's literary career, however, soon took a back seat to events overseas. Despite a mild heart condition, Salinger volunteered to fight in World War II and was sent to serve in Europe. One of the few bright spots during his time in Europe was meeting the writer Ernest Hemingway, with whom Salinger developed a lasting correspondence.

While Salinger's experience of the war certainly left him traumatized, when he returned to New York, he more or less picked up where he left off. Before the war, he had started writing a series of stories about a young man who suffers a nervous breakdown in the middle of Manhattan. These would later form the basis for Salinger's first and only novel, The Catcher in the Rye, published in 1951.

Parallels between Holden Caulfield's and Salinger's lives are evident, especially as far as their educational careers are concerned. The Catcher in the Rye begins with Caulfield on the verge of expulsion from boarding school, after already having been kicked out of two previous schools. He leaves his prestigious New England prep school for a two-day adventure in New York City, and meets characters from walks of life he had never encountered within his privileged milieu.
What drew the acclaim of critics and readers alike was the authenticity of Caulfield's inner
monologue. He is shown to be not just a "'rebel without a cause," but a thoughtful and clever
young man, astutely critical of society and its "'phoniness," yet at the same time, desiring
acceptance from it. Some critics have gone so far as to suggest that Holden Caulfield was the archetype for modern "bad boy" culture heroes such as James Dean.

Salinger would go on to publish numerous other stories in The New Yorker over the next decade. The most famous of them, published in book form in 1961, was Franny and Zooey, about the relationship between a gifted brother and sister who, each in their own way, struggle with the expectations of maturity. Other noteworthy stories written in this period include: Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymore, an Introduction.

After Hapsworth 16, 1924 was published in 1965, Salinger mysteriously withdrew from the public eye. Living more or less as a recluse in rural New Hampshire, Salinger has ceased to submit anything for publication, and rarely, if ever, gives interviews.

Some observers suspect that Salinger's withdrawal from society is indicative of a mental breakdown of some sort; in this respect, at least, perhaps Salinger has much more in common with his maladjusted characters than most people may have realized.

question-stem.para: The word disaffectedin the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: condemned
alienated
complicated
despised

explanation.para: Disaffected means resentful against authority. Alienated means estranged or separated from
others, which is similar in meaning. The clue to meaning is in paragraph 1: "'the struggle to
reconcile." Although the young people were emotionally (C) complicated and may hove (D) despised authority, these words are not synonyms of disaffected. (D) condemned is incorrect.

question-stem.para: The word acclaim in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: disdain
criticism
interest
praise

explanation.para: Praise is a synonym of acclaim. The clue to meaning is in the same sentence: "'authenticity,"
which means Salinger created a believable character. This can only be accomplished by a
good writer and would be worthy of praise, (A) Disdain and (8) criticism are opposite in meaning. (C) Interest implies no judgment; the job of a critic is to judge.

question-stem.para: The word astutely in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: shrewdly
unnecessarily
silently
significantly

explanation.para: Astutely and shrewdly are synonyms, both meaning perceptive. The clue to meaning is in the same sentence : Caulfield is a "thoughtful and clever" young man who is "'critical of

. .. ;" offering thoughtful criticism is a result of perception. Caulfield is not (C) silent (quiet) in his criticism . (B) Unnecessarily critical would imply there was no real reason to be critical, which is not true.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, one of the main themes that concerned J.D. Salinger was

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: the difficulties young people faced as they entered adulthood
the pressures society placed on individuals to conform
the ability of a single individual to change a society
the importance of serving those in need

explanation.para: Paragraph 1 states that the theme running throughout Salinger's work was that of youth struggling to reconcile innocence with the expectations of the world (A). Examples of these struggles in his work are noted in paragraphs 5 and 7. Items (B) and (C) are elements of Salinger's work, but are too narrow in scope. (D) is not mentioned in the passage.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, Salinger

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: graduated from New York University
attended a private high school
dropped out of high school
did not finish college

explanation.para: This detail is presented in paragraph 2: "He dropped out of several colleges ... " To "drop out" is to leave before finishing (D). (A) is attractive because he went to colleges in New York but it doesn't say he went to New York University; (B) is attractive because a military academy can be confused with private school-in addition, Caulfield attended a private school; (C) is attractive because he did "drop out" of school, but it was college, not high school.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, Holden Caulfield is similar to J .D. Salinger in that

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: he is about the same age
he wants to be a writer
he has attended several different schools
he is interested in popular culture

explanation.para: This detail (C) is presented in paragraph 5, where the "parallel" between the writer and his character's educational career is noted. (A) is attractive because Caulfield's struggles occurred at the same age as Salinger's. (B) is noted only about Salinger. (D) is attractive because they both struggle with culture and fitting in, which is not the same as showing an "interest" (detached observation) in popular culture.

question-stem.para: It can be inferred that Salinger was considered

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: unstable
rebellious
a model citizen
a hero for youth

explanation.para: (A) Unstable in this context means having a lack of emotional control. The author states in the last paragraph that some people suspect Salinger became a recluse because he'd had a mental breakdown. (B) is attractive because Salinger dropped out of school and his characters were rebellious. (C) is attractive because Salinger's character Caulfield became an "archetype," which is a model or prototype. (D) is attractive because
Salinger created the archetype for a "culture hero."

question-stem.para: The author recounts the plot of The Catcher in the Rye in paragraph 5 in order to
Paragraph 5 is marked with an arrow [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: make the passage more entertaining
illustrate a similarity between Caulfield and Salinger
demonstrate how unconventional the novel was
support the claim that the novel's protagonist revolutionized popular culture

explanation.para: In sentence 1 of paragraph 5 the author states that there are parallels between the lives of Salinger and Caulfield (B). After the plot is summarized, it is left to the reader to relate these events to Salinger's life in paragraph 2. The concepts of entertainment (A), unconventionality (B), and revolution (D) are not noted in paragraph 5.

question-stem.para: There are four squares [ ] in the passage. These squares represent places where the sentence below could be added to the passage.

para.emphasis: The horrors and tragedies of what he saw there affected him deeply.

question-stem.para: Where would the sentence best fit?
Click on the square [ ] in the passage where the sentence fits the best.

insert-sentence.sentence: The horrors and tragedies of what he saw there affected him deeply.

explanation.para: In this passage, the noun phrase "horrors and tragedies of what he saw there" could only apply to war, which is the topic of the sentence preceding (C). Also, the word there implies place, which is another clue to establishing coherence. The "places" noted in the other three positions are not related to war: (A) Salinger's lie; (B) Greenwich Village; (D) New York.

question-stem.para: The word These in the passage refers to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Salinger's war experiences
Salinger's literary influences
Stories Salinger began writing before the war
Publishers to whom Salinger submitted his work.

explanation.para: The pronominal referent must precede the word these and must "form the basis" (or foundation) of Salinger's novel. Stories form the foundation of a book. A "series of stories" (C) is noted in the preceding sentence. His war experiences (A) were mentioned too early in the paragraph to be a referent for these. Neither publishers (D) nor literary influences (B) are mentioned in the passage.

question-stem.para: Which of the following best expresses the essential information in the highlighted sentence in the passage? Incorrect choices change the meaning in important ways or leave out essential information

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: After The Catcher in the Rye, popular culture became more appreciative of rebellious, troubled figures.
Despite the example set by Holden Caulfield, youth heroes became more rebellious.
Holden Caulfield was inspired by figures like James Dean.
The Catcher in the Rye was based loosely on events in the life of James Dean.

explanation.para: Essential information noted in the highlighted sentence includes "bad boy" which means a rebellious, troubled figure, and "modern ... culture," which means popular culture (A). That Salinger's bad boy archetype became a culture hero implies the culture appreciated (liked) the archetype. The other choices are incorrect because they do not paraphrase the sentence nor they are not true.

question-stem.para: Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the author's opinion about J.D. Salinger?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He is the most important author of the twentieth century.
He imitated the style of Ernest Hemingway.
His short stories are much stronger than his novels.
His troubled characters are based on his own experiences.

explanation.para: The author parallels Salinger's life with Caulfield's in paragraph 5. In paragraph 1 it is stated that the theme of reconciling innocence with reality runs through both Salinger's work and life. It is stated in paragraph 9 that Salinger had in common with his characters a mental breakdown. All of these details make (D) the correct answer. None of the other choices are true, although each contains an element that is mentioned: Salinger is an acclaimed author, corresponds with Hemmingway, and writes short stories

question-stem.para: Directions: The sentence below is an introductory sentence for a short summary of the passage. Select THREE answer choices from the chart that represent important ideas in the passage. Some sentences are incorrect because they contain information that was not in the passage or contain information that is a minor detail. This question is worth 2 points.

para.emphasis: J.D. Salinger is an important figure in American literature.

question-stem.para: Use the mouse to drag the answer choices to the spaces where they belong. To remove an answer; choice, click on it. To look at the reading passage again, click on 'View Text.'

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He created a memorable character who defined a generation.
He is considered the founder of a new genre of literature
The life of his most famous character paralleled that of his own.
The language used by his characters became the language of youth culture.
Contemporary critics considered his use of inner monologue as a literary device revolutionary
After a prosperous writing career, he withdrew from public life.

explanation.para: (A) Salinger's character who defined a generation is noted in paragraph 1. (C) That Caulfield paralleled his own life is noted in paragraph 5. (F) That Salinger withdrew from public life is noted in the last paragraph.

(B) is attractive because Salinger's character established an archetype, but this is not the same as creating a new genre of literature. (D) is incorrect because Salinger's writing captured the voice of disaffected youth, it did not create a new mode of expression. (E) is incorrect because Salinger masterfully used this device, he did not revolutionize (change) it.

para.emphasis: American Neoclassicism and the U.S. Capitol Building

passage.para: Visitors to America's capital city, Washington, D.C., have long been impressed by its majestic, white stone buildings and one in particular: the U.S. Capitol. With its lofty dome, triangular pediment depicting various historical scenes, and supporting row of columns, the building hearkens back to the temples of ancient Greece and Rome. These design elements, replicated in countless public buildings in the capital and around the country, were more than mere flights of fancy on the part of its designers. The building's visionaries were attempting to anchor the young democracy to the very cradle of Western civilization, while at the same time asserting the nation's own unique identity.

This incorporation of classic Greek and Roman motifs in art and architecture—neoclassicism, as the movement came to be called—was not a novel idea at the time of the Capitol's design. The emerging field of archaeology yielded several previously undiscovered Roman ruins in the early 18th century, renewing appreciation for Greco-Roman architectural sophistication. Enthusiasm for these physical forms was closely tied to the political and philosophical principles the re resented: democracy and rationalism. This was especially the case later in the century, as the ferment of democratic revolution grew, and archaeologists made spectacular discoveries at Pompeii and Herculaneum.

Imported from Great Britain, neoclassicism found expression in the American colonies, primarily in New England, and in the buildings of Edmund Woolley and Ebenezer Tomlinson. The Pennsylvania Statehouse (later named Independence Hall) is an outstanding example of American neoclassicism as it existed before the Revolutionary War, Due to material and technical limitations, innovations were mostly confined to detail and ornamentation. It was not until after the Revolution and the opportunity it afforded to fashion a capital city from the ground up that American neoclassicism assumed its unique and monumental character.

The American statesman most responsible for this shift was Thomas Jefferson, an architect in his own right. Unlike his New England compatriots, Jefferson's classical inspiration came largely by way of France, where he had spent a great deal of time before the Revolution and later as ambassador under President Washington. In the throes of its own democratic revolution, France similarly looked to the ancient world in erecting its new institutions and monuments. Jefferson was awed by Roman ruins, as well as more recent constructions that sought to resurrect not just the details, but the very scale and grandeur of ancient Roman temples.

Jefferson was emotionally and administratively involved in almost all aspects of the capital's design and construction, including the decision to entrust the task of planning the new city to tho French officer Charles L'Enfant. Jefferson's sensibilities were also reflected in the design for the capitol building, approved in a public competition in 1793. Submitted by William Thornton, the plan was reminiscent of the Roman Pantheon, with its distinctive circular rotunda, colonnade and dome. Jefferson's fondness for the style, and the dome in particular, could be seen in the way he fashioned his own famous estate, Monticello. It is thus not surprising that this period is alternately referred to as the Idealistic or Jeffersonian era of American neoclassicism, and that the dome has become one of its defining features.

Before it was completed in 1826, the Capitol building went through four a architects and one complete reconstruction after being burnt to the ground by the British in 1812. While its final form did not deviate greatly from Thornton's original design, the building's final architect, Benjamin Latrobe, is credited with imbuing the Capitol with a distinctively American sensibility. One of the building's most admired features, said to have been suggested by Jefferson, reflects this synthesis: the columns in the rotunda , whose orders were adorned with American crops like tobacco leaves and corn. It is a fitting irony that Latrobe, who has been given the title of America's first professional architect and would go on to design some of the country's most celebrated edifices, was an immigrant from England.

question-stem.para: The word motifs in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: goals
themes
ruins
artists

explanation.para: A motif is a central theme (B). A clue to meaning is in the same sentence: "movement,"which in art and architecture implies a central organizing theme. (A) goals and (C) artist; are incorrect; neither could be incorporated into art and architecture. (C) ruins is attractive because ancient temples were mentioned in the previous paragraph.

question-stem.para: The word it in paragraph 3 refers to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: capital city
monumental character
the Revolution
American neoclassicism

explanation.para: The pronominal referent must precede the word it. Part of the challenge here is to understand the function of it within this clause. Meaning becomes clearer if the clause is reordered such that the object follows the verb: "it afforded (made available) the opportunity to fashion (create) a capital city. The Revolution (C) made available such an opportunity. The other choices are attractive because they appear in the same paragraph.

question-stem.para: The words reminiscent of in the passage are closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: similar to
smaller than
copied from
confused with

explanation.para: Reminiscent comes from the word remember and means a tendency to remind, which would require that the two items be (A) similar to each other. (C) copied from is attractive, because a copy would certainly remind one of the original. (D) confused with is attractive because two items that are similar might be confused with each other. (B) smaller than is incorrect.

question-stem.para: The word fondness in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: familiarity
talent
labor
liking

explanation.para: (D) liking is a synonym of fondness. (A) familiarity is attractive because Jefferson would

have to be familiar with the style in order to use in fashioning his own estate, but familiarity can be eliminated because it requires the preposition with, not for (which follows fondness). (B) talent and (C) labor are incorrect.

question-stem.para: Which of the following best expresses the essential information in the highlighted sentence in the passage? Incorrect choices change the meaning in important ways or leave out essential information.

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: A lack of resources limited the expression of neoclassical architectural features in America
American colonists preferred to express neoclassicism in details rather than grand designs.
The only expressions of neoclassicism in America were seen in ornamentation.
Technical difficulties prevented American neoclassicists from attending to details.

explanation.para: Essential information noted in the highlighted sentence includes: "material and technical limitations," which means a lack of resources; "mostly confined to," which is paraphrased by "limited the expression of" and "detail and ornamentation," which is referred to as "architectural features." All of these are found in (A). Two other choices can be quickly eliminated because the paraphrased sentences use words contrary to the original statement: (B) preference is not noted; and (C) only implies severe restriction, the original uses mostly. (D) is incorrect because, due to technical limitations, neoclassicists "were mostly confined to details," not prevented from using detail.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, the original designer of the U.S. Capitol was

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Ebenezer Tomlinson
Thomas Jefferson
William Thornton
Benjamin Latrobe

explanation.para: This detail is presented in paragraph 5, where it is stated that William Thornton (C) submitted a plan. The preceding sentence states that a public competition was held for design of the Capitol. (A) is attractive because Ebenezer Tomlinson applied neoclassicist design principles to buildings in Pennsylvania. (B) is attractive because Thomas Jefferson influenced the design of the Capitol. (D) is attractive because Benjamin Latrobe was the final architect of the Capitol.

question-stem.para: In the passage, all of the following are given as reasons for the rise of neoclassicism EXCEPT

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: the development of the field of archaeology
political revolution
the discoveries at Pompeii
Washington's time spent in France

explanation.para: Paragraph 2 states that archaeological discoveries led to increased interest in neoclassicism; thus (A) is not the answer. Paragraph 4 states that one result of the French Revolution was an interest in neoclassicism; thus (B) is not the answer. (C) is related to (A); paragraph 2 states that the discoveries at Pompeii were "especially" connected to "enthusiasm" for neoclassical forms. This leaves (D) as the answer; no mention is made of Washington spending time in France or of Washington being connected to the rise of neoclassicism (it was Jefferson who spent time in France and who later was interested in neoclassicism).

question-stem.para: All of the following are true about Thomas Jefferson EXCEPT

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He admired Greco-Roman architecture
He hired Charles L'Enfant to build Monticello
He served as ambassador to France
He was involved in the planning and design of Washington, D.C.

explanation.para: Here, it is essential to find the statement that is NOT true. (C) is correct because in paragraph five it states that Jefferson "fashioned [designed] his own famous estate, Monticello," therefore he could not have hired Charles L'Enfant to do it, Jefferson did hire L'Enfant to design the capital city. The other choices are all true (and therefore not the correct answer): (A) is noted in paragraph 3; (C) is noted in paragraph 4; (D) is noted in paragraph 5.

question-stem.para: In paragraph two, the author explains the interest in neoclassicism in the 18th century by
Paragraph 2 is marked with an arrow [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: discussing the discovery of archaeological sites from ancient Greece and Rome
demonstrating the connection between democratic revolutions and ancient Greece
pointing out the European royalty's admiration for ancient Rome
asserting that European culture had been influenced by ancient Greece and Rome for centuries

explanation.para: In sentence 2 of paragraph 2, the author notes that the "emerging field of archaeology" yielded new discoveries of Roman ruins and thus renewed appreciation for Greco-Roman architecture (A). The author then links the new enthusiasm to the growing interest in democracy. (B) is attractive because democratic revolution is mentioned; however, no connection to ancient Greece is made. (C) is incorrect; royalty is not mentioned. (D) is incorrect; neither culture nor centuries are mentioned.

question-stem.para: There are four squares [ ] in the passage. These squares represent places where the sentence below could be added to the passage.

para.emphasis: Jefferson carried this grand vision back to America with him.

question-stem.para: Where would the sentence best fit?
Click on the square [ ] in the passage where the sentence fits the best.

insert-sentence.sentence: Jefferson carried this grand vision back to America with him.

explanation.para: There are two main ideas in the new sentence: "grand vision" and "carried ... back to America with him." The sentence preceding (D) discusses subject matter that qualifies as a grand vision: new construction that "sought to resurrect ... the very scale and grandeur of ancient Roman temples" This passage also discusses Jefferson's visit to France, which would lead naturally to a statement about bringing an idea "back to America." Passages preceding the other choices are incorrect because: (A) Edmund Woolley and Ebenezer Tomlinson are noted, not Jefferson; (B) no mention of travel is made; (C) classical inspiration is noted, but is not discussed as a grand vision.

question-stem.para: An important feature of American neoclassicism is

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: artwork depicting American crops
ornamentation
a dome
Greek inscriptions

explanation.para: This detail is presented in the last sentence of paragraph 5 where it is stated that the dome (C) became one of the defining features of American neoclassicism. (A) is attractive because depiction of American crops on the columns in the Capitol's rotunda is noted in paragraph 6. However, it is not said that this feature appeared regularly American neoclassicism. Ornamentation (B) is too general to be a defining feature; most architectural styles have ornamentation. (D) Greek inscriptions are not mentioned in the passage.

question-stem.para: Directions: Select the appropriate names and phrases and match them with the period of American neoclassicism with which they are associated. This question is worth 2 points.
Use the mouse to drag the answer choices to the spaces where they belong. To remove an answer choice from the placeholder, click on it. To look at the reading passage again, click on 'View Text.'

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Jeffersonian era
Edmund Wooley
Wrought-iron railings
Pennsylvania Statehouse
Benjamin Latrobe
United States Capitol
Pantheon
George Washington

explanation.para: In order to answer this question, you must understand that the U.S. Capitol (F) was not built until after the American Revolution, and you must select answers that relate to American neoclassicism.

Pre-Revolution American Neoclassicism: (B) Edmund Wooley and (D) the Pennsylvania Statehouse are correct because paragraph 3 clearly states that Edmund Wooley was one of the people who designed the Pennsylvania Statehouse "before the Revolutionary War."

Post-Revolution American Neoclassicism: In paragraph 5, the Jeffersonian era (A) is linked to the building of the U.S. Capitol, which expressed neoclassicism. Benjamin Latrobe (E) was the Capitol's (F) final architect.

None: (C) is not mentioned in the passage. (G) is attractive because the Capitol is "reminiscent" of the Pantheon; however, the Pantheon is not an American building, nor is it neoclassical. (H) is not an answer because George Washington is only mentioned briefly in the passage (he was president when Jefferson was ambassador to France), and not in relation to neoclassicism.

question-stem.para: Directions: Select the appropriate names and phrases and match them with the period of American neoclassicism with which they are associated. This question is worth 2 points.
Use the mouse to drag the answer choices to the spaces where they belong. To remove an answer choice from the placeholder, click on it. To look at the reading passage again, click on 'View Text.'

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Jeffersonian era
Edmund Wooley
Wrought-iron railings
Pennsylvania Statehouse
Benjamin Latrobe
United States Capitol
Pantheon
George Washington

explanation.para: In order to answer this question, you must understand that the U.S. Capitol (F) was not built until after the American Revolution, and you must select answers that relate to American neoclassicism.

Pre-Revolution American Neoclassicism: (B) Edmund Wooley and (D) the Pennsylvania Statehouse are correct because paragraph 3 clearly states that Edmund Wooley was one of the people who designed the Pennsylvania Statehouse "before the Revolutionary War."

Post-Revolution American Neoclassicism: In paragraph 5, the Jeffersonian era (A) is linked to the building of the U.S. Capitol, which expressed neoclassicism. Benjamin Latrobe (E) was the Capitol's (F) final architect.

None: (C) is not mentioned in the passage. (G) is attractive because the Capitol is "reminiscent" of the Pantheon; however, the Pantheon is not an American building, nor is it neoclassical. (H) is not an answer because George Washington is only mentioned briefly in the passage (he was president when Jefferson was ambassador to France), and not in relation to neoclassicism.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, what is the significance of the designs found on the columns in the Capitol's rotunda?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: They reflect the use of distinctly American stone-working technique.
They show the genius of Benjamin Latrobe.
They are a uniquely American expression of neoclassicism
They demonstrate Thomas Jefferson's willingness to compromise on design decisions.

explanation.para: The main idea of the passage is how neoclassicism is expressed in American architecture. In the last paragraph the author notes that the designs on the rotunda's columns reflect a distinctly American sensibility." This detail (C) relates to the main idea. The other three choices are not true.

para.emphasis: Agonistic Displays

passage.para: Animals exhibit many kinds of display behavior. Among the most familiar are courtship displays used when animals intend to mate. Another well-known set of display patterns are termed agonistic ; these are displays used by animals in situations involving attack, escape, or fear. Scientists have discovered that there are three discrete types of motor patterns used as basic building blocks for agonistic displays, all of which arise out of conflict between competing emotional motivations. Most agonistic displays are derived from these three sets of motor patterns.

The first motor pattern consists of irrelevant actions, which animal behaviorists call displacement activities. These are actions that appear to be performed in inappropriate contexts. In one experimental setting, male Wood Thrushes put in a position that required a choice between attacking or fleeing would begin to scratch, or clean their wings, eat, or even sleep. Examples of a displacement activity in humans would be chewing one's nails or drumming one's fingers on the table when nervous, or whistling when scared. In such situations, there seems to be a feeling that an action-any action-is called for, whether it is appropriate or not. Displacement activities usually consist of actions normally associated with parts of an individual's daily maintenance routine-actions such as preening, scratching, yawning, stretching, and eating.

The second motor pattern consists of actions performed in the correct contexts, but directed towards the wrong objects, and are called redirected activities. These are most common when an initial intention is thwarted, or otherwise unable to be completed. For example, a male bird might be unable or unwilling to risk attacking another larger bird invading his territory, and in stead peck at the branch upon which he is perched. A dog on a leash might be tempted to bite another dog, but restrained by its owner from doing so, it tries to bite its owner or a nearby object. An employee angry with his boss might yell at a friend or relative. Redirected activities, like displacement activities, arise out of conflict between motivations, and convey information about the emotional state of the animal.

The third motor pattern consists of uncompleted initial stages of ordinary actions, called intention movements. Examples would be birds crouching just before taking off, or someone making a fist before hitting another person. The bird may not actually take off, and a person may not actually strike the opponent, but the intent has been signaled. An emotional conflict arises out of whether to follow through on the act once it has been signaled as having begun. These intention movements reveal information about the animal's emotional state.

Displacement activities, redirected activities, and intention movements all convey information about the animal's motivations and emotional state. Over time, exaggeration and stereotyping ritualize these behaviors and incorporate them into displays. The exaggeration and stereotyping of the components of a display are important in creating unambiguous communication. If the movements vary too much between individuals within a species, or in one individual over time, then the information content becomes less clear.

While the information content of an agonistic display may be clear to the animals involved, it is less so to the scientists who study displays. Several key questions about agonistic displays remain unanswered: Do displays always reveal the true intentions of an animal? Do animals ever use displays to bluff or lie about their intentions?

Some scientists argue that it makes sense for animals to bluff. If a display signaling a readiness to attack a rival over a food resource results in the rival's departure, then it is worth signaling, even if there is no true resolve to fight. In theory, an animal that always signals it intends to attack, regardless of its actual intention, will initially win more contests than one that signals honestly.

However, other researchers have pointed out that if winning contests plays a major role in gaining reproductive success, cheaters sending false signals would spread through the population rapidly, Soon, others would learn to ignore these signals. If the reliability of the information contained in the display decreases over time, eventually there would no point in reacting to it.
Much more research is needed before scientists have a full understanding of the complex information content and actual uses of agonistic displays.

question-stem.para: Based on the information in paragraph 1, agonistic display patterns

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: involve injury, pain, or suffering
help others through self-sacrifice
have to do with attacking, escaping, or being afraid
show intent to perform an action before it is actually performed

explanation.para: In paragraph 1, agonistic is defined as "display used by animals in situations involving attack, escape, or fear." Therefore, (C) is correct. (A) is attractive because an animal might suffer injury or pain in such a situation. (B) is not mentioned. (D) is attractive because "intention movements" are mentioned in paragraph 4.

question-stem.para: The word discrete in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: distinct
similar
cautious
unknown

explanation.para: In this sentence discrete is an adjective modifying the word types. Discrete means separate or distinct (A). The passage goes on to describe three distinct types of motor patterns, which is a clue to meaning. (B) similar is attractive because the sentence speaks about building blocks, which might lead one to guess that the types of motor patterns are similar. (C) cautious is attractive because agonistic behaviors deal with situations that call for caution. (D) unknown is incorrect; a clue to meaning is that the passage goes on to describe the patterns, which would be impossible if they were unknown.

question-stem.para: What do animal behaviorists call acts that seem to be inappropriate for their contexts?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: bluffing
redirected activities
agnostic movements
displacement activities

explanation.para: This question requires you to link information in two sentences. The first sentence of paragraph 2 describes "irrelevant actions" called displacement activities (D). The following sentence states the actions are inappropriate for their contexts. (A) bluffing is not discussed in relation to any particular pattern typo (paragraphs 6 and 7). In addition, it would not be inappropriate for an animal to bluff a rival over a food source. (B) redirected activities is incorrect; see paragraph 3. (C) agonistic movements is attractive because all the movement patterns are agonistic; this answer is too general.

question-stem.para: The word thwarted in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: replaced
prevented
attempted
destroyed

explanation.para: Thwarted means to oppose successfully, which in this case would stop or (B) prevent the action. A clue to meaning is in the next clause : "unable to be completed." (A) replaced is attractive because the paragraph describes animals that direct action toward wrong objects, and thus could be said to replace one object for another. (C) attempted is attractive because an animal may attempt one action and have to redirect its behavior. (D) destroyed means to put out of existence, which makes it attractive. However, the intention is not eliminated; it continues to exist, but is prevented.

question-stem.para: The word itin paragraph 3 refers to
Paragraph 3 is marked with an arrow [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: a dog
a leash
a temptation
an object

explanation.para: The pronominal referent must precede the word It and must possess the ability to "try to bite its owner." The first clause of the sentence notes a dog that "might be tempted to bite," therefore (D) dog is the correct answer. (B) a leash, (C) a temptation, and (D) an object are incorrect and could be eliminated quickly as none can bite its owner.

question-stem.para: The word state in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: country
express
explain
condition

explanation.para: In this sentence state is used as a noun and is modified by the adjective emotional, which is a clue to meaning: emotional condition (D) . Of the 4 words presented, only (A) country and (D) condition are nouns. (A) is attractive because a state is part of a country, however, it can be eliminated because a country cannot be described as emotional. (B) express and (C) explain, both verbs, are attractive because they are synonyms of state in its verb form.

question-stem.para: An important factor in creating display patterns is

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: vocalization of intent
repetition of complex acts
stereotyping of behaviors
recognition of individual's markings

explanation.para: This detail is presented in paragraph 5. Stereotyping (C) is mentioned in the second and third sentences. The importance of this factor in creating display patterns is explained in sentences 3 and 4. (A) is not mentioned. (B) is attractive because stereotyping can be defined as the repetition of complex acts . (D) is not mentioned.

question-stem.para: Which of the following is mentioned as a potential cause for miscommunication?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Variation in display movements
Display movements that are similar
Poor execution of display movements
Introduction of new display movements

explanation.para: This detail (A) is presented in the last sentence of paragraph 5. A due to meaning is the phrase "unambiguous [clear] communication" in the preceding sentence, which locates the topic of communication. One must also understand that in the last sentence, "information content becomes less clear" means that miscommunication occurs. (B), (C), and (D) are attractive because each would logically result in miscommunication, however, none of these are mentioned.

question-stem.para: In paragraph 6, the author illustrates that there are unresolved issues regarding information content in agonistic displays by
Paragraph 6 is marked with an arrow [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: posing questions
citing examples of faulty research
describing the problems in detail
quoting the works of a well-known scientist

explanation.para: In the first sentence of this paragraph the author introduces the idea that the information content of agonistic displays may be unclear to scientists. The author then poses or asks questions (A), each of which opens an area of doubt to be examined. Authors often use this device to illustrate unresolved issues. (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect.

question-stem.para: Which of the following best expresses the essential information in the highlighted sentence in the passage? Incorrect choices change the meaning in important ways or leave out essential information.

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: If an animal does not have the resolve to fight, it should not signal a readiness to attack.
When signaling willingness to fight is enough to scare away rivals, then it should be done.
By attacking rivals for food resources, an animal signals that it is superior and therefore the best mate.
It is worth signaling the ownership of a rival's food resource if the rival does not have the resolve to fight.

explanation.para: Essential information noted in the highlighted sentence includes three key phrases that are paraphrased in (B). "Readiness to attack" can be paraphrased as "willingness to fight." "Results in the rival's departure" is similar to "'scare away rivals," although the original phrase does not include the concept of fear. "Then it is worth signaling" implies "it should be done." The meaning of the second clause in (A) is contrary to that of the highlighted statement. (C) is incorrect; the quality of being a superior mate is not mentioned. (D) is incorrect; not having the resolve to fight is mentioned in relation to the animal that attacks a rival, not the rival.

question-stem.para: There are four squares [ ] in the passage. These squares represent places where the sentence below could be added to the passage.

para.emphasis: Dishonest most likely results in the extinction of a display behavior.

question-stem.para: Where would the sentence best fit?
Click on the square [ ] in the passage where the sentence fits the best.

insert-sentence.sentence: Dishonest most likely results in the extinction of a display behavior.

explanation.para: The key to coherence here is found in the words dishonesty and extinction. The sentence preceding (C) discusses tho reliability of information that decreases over time1 which forms a link to dishonesty. This sentence also introduces the idea of no longer reacting to a display, which leads naturally to a statement about the extinction (elimination) of a display behavior. (A) is attractive because dishonesty can be confused with information content becoming less dear. But dishonesty requires intent to deceive, which is not a factor here. (B) is attractive because honestly appears in the preceding sentence. But, t his sentence indicates that an animal that signals dishonestly will win, which is opposite in meaning to the new sentence. (D) is entirely unrelated.

question-stem.para: Based on the information in paragraph 7 and paragraph 8, what can be inferred about bluffing?
Paragraph 7 and paragraph 8 are marked with arrows [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It is not a genetic trait.
Most animals will bluff under certain conditions.
There is no scientific evidence to suggest that animals bluff.
Scientists disagree as to whether it is advantageous for animals to bluff.

explanation.para: Paragraph 7 discusses why scientists believe that it would be advantageous for animals to bluff, and paragraph 8 takes the opposite position. Thus, the author infers that scientists disagree (D). (A) is incorrect; the author infers that bluffing Is a genetic trait by stating that "cheaters would spread through the population rapidly ." (B) is incorrect; neither paragraph states that animals actually bluff. Both paragraphs discuss imagined behavior. (C) is incorrect; while both paragraphs discuss imagined behavior--which is not scientific evidence--the concept of lack of scientific evidence is not mentioned.

question-stem.para: Directions: The sentence below is an introductory sentence for a short summary of the passage. Select THREE answer choices from the chart that represent important ideas in the passage. Some sentences are incorrect because they contain information that was not in the passage or contain information that is a minor detail. This question is worth 2 points.

para.emphasis: The components of agonistic displays arise from conflicting emotional motivations and can be characterized as belonging to one of three basic categories.

question-stem.para: Use the mouse to drag the answer choices tothe spaces where they belong. To remove an answer choice, click on it. To look at the reading passage again, click on 'View Text.'

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Animal behaviorists recognize displacement activities, redirected activities, and intention movements as being the building blocks of all agonistic displays.
All emotional motivations are centered on enhancing access to food, shelter", and mates.
Agonistic displays convey information about an animal's emotional frame of mind.
Of these three, intention movements convey the most information , and are therefore the most likely to be observed.
The three categories of behavior animal behaviorists most often display are displacement activities, redirected activities, and intention movements.
Exaggeration and stereotyping of these three components is important in creating the final displays .

explanation.para: A summary of the passage should note the 3 types of agonistic displays, which (A) does successfully. Competing emotional motivations (C) are identified in paragraph 1 as basic to agonistic displays; this idea is restated in paragraph s. Paragraph 5 states that exaggeration and stereotyping are important.

(B) and (D) do not appear in the passage. Throughout the passage, the word display appears as a noun or an adjective (e.g., display pattern). (E) uses display as a verb and incorrectly attributes the action to behaviorists .

question-stem.para: What does the librarian say about the printer?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It is not working.
It is slow
It requires a pass code to use.
It is on the second floor.

explanation.para: Because the librarian says that the printer is a little slow and that the student may have to wait a minute or two for it to print, (B) is correct. (A) is contrary to fact (it is working). The printer requires an 10 number, not a pass code (C), and there is no mention of the floor where the printer is located (D).

question-stem.para: Why is little known about the Caribbean monk seal?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It lived in extremely remote parts of the Caribbean sea.
It never attracted the interest of scientists.
It was difficult to catch in the wild.
It became extinct before scientists could study it in-depth.

explanation.para: The professor begins his lecture by stating that little is known about the Caribbean monk seal because it was not studied in depth until after it had vanished (D). (B) contradicts this statement, so it is wrong. (A) and (C) are not mentioned as reasons why little is known about the species.

question-stem.para: What does the professor say about the 1908 Tunguska asteroid?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It came down only 200 miles from Tunguska.
It hit Earth with a force equal to about 15 million tons of TNT.
It was the last asteroid to hit Earth.
It landed in a low-population area.

explanation.para: The professor states specifically that the Tunguska impact contained roughly the same about of force as 15 million tons of TNT (B). He also states that the area was nearly uninhibited, which means it had a low-population (D). It was a 200-foot asteroid, not 200 miles away (A), We don't know (C) to be a fact.

question-stem.para: How does the professor characterize the spoken language children use before they enter school?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: As primarily short sentences using simple words and phrases
As more advanced than the language they use in reading and writing
As centered on contexts involving "here" and "now"
As grammatically inaccurate most of the time

explanation.para: The professor states that the conversations of pre-schoolers are usually about things and people "here" and "now," so (C) is correct. (A) is incorrect because the professor states that written sentences are longer (than spoken sentences), but she doesn't limit this characteristic to pre-schoolers. (B) is false, and while she states that, in general, there are grammatical errors in spoken language, she does not state that pre-school children make mistakes in their language use "most of the time," so (D) is not correct.

question-stem.para: What reason did the student give for starting a new job?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He needs more spending money.
He needs money to pay for school.
He wants valuable work experience.
He wants to earn credit towards graduation.

explanation.para: (B) is correct because the student had to take on (accept) extra work in order to pay for the rise in tuition, to earn more money for college, not to spend on other miscellaneous things (A). There is no mention that he wants the work experience (C) or that he will receive college credit for his work (D).

question-stem.para: What does the student say regarding his work?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: His bakery job does not have a set schedule.
His Environmental Systems job ends in four weeks.
His job at the bakery conflicts with the class schedule.
His Environmental Systems job begins at the end of the semester.

explanation.para: (B) is correct because the student says that his job will last only another four weeks. His bakery job's hours are late at night and do not conflict with his class hours (A, C). His Environmental Systems job ends in four weeks, one week after the midterm (mid-semester), rather than starting at the end (D).

question-stem.para: What does the professor suggest that the student do?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Drop the class
Reduce the number of hours he works
Get ahead on the course reading
Attend a later class section

explanation.para: (D) is correct because the professor offers the student a position in the 10:00 A.M. class instead of in his current 8:00 A.M. class. Though the other three options are logical, the professor does not mention them to the student so they are incorrect.

question-stem.para: Why does the Professor say this?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To indicate agreement with the student
To encourage the student to elaborate
To ask the student to repeat his question
To end the discussion with the student

explanation.para: (A) is correct because the function of the idiomatic expression "tell me about it" is to indicate agreement, so the professor supports the student's statement that the buses run late in the morning. The expression does not request additional information (B), nor does it indicate that she does not understand what he has said (C). There is also no indication that the discussion will stop (D).

question-stem.para: What can be inferred about the student's performance in class this semester?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He has had good grades and attendance until recently.
He is unlikely to improve his attendance.
His grades have been decreasing steadily.
His poor attendance has lowered his grade.

question-stem.para: What is the topic of the article the student needs?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: East Asian politics
Classical Greek poetry
World history
Japanese literature

explanation.para: (D) is correct because the student says she is studying Japanese literature, specifically Classical Japanese Poetry (poetry is one form of literature). (A) is attractive because Japan is in East Asia, but the student is not studying politics. (D) is attractive because it repeats the words classical and poetry. (C) is not mentioned.

question-stem.para: Why does the librarian say this?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To indicate that the student has not given him the correct Information
To inform the student that she has entered the wrong journal title into the computer
To find out whether the student knows how to use a database function
To aid the student in finding additional articles by the same author

explanation.para: (A) is correct because the function of the expression "but what about the journal title" is to indicate that the librarian needs this information to help her. (C) is attractive because earlier the student says she is having trouble finding the information she needs, but the librarian is not implying anything about her understanding of databases here. Neither (B) or (D) is mentioned in the dialogue, nor are they implied in any way.

question-stem.para: Why does the librarian say this?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To indicate that he is repeating a previous instruction
To indicate that the student will need to enter the article title again
To indicate that the student needs to choose a different option
To indicate that he is unsure about what the student wants

explanation.para: (A) is correct because the function of the expression so again is to highlight the fact that the librarian is repeating something he has already stated. The student is asked to select a subtopic, not the title of an article (B). He does not ask the student to change her topic (C). It is clear that the librarian understands what the student wants (D), not that he is unsure.

question-stem.para: What will the student probably do next?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Print an article
Check the journal out from the library
Show the librarian her student ID
Save an article to a disk

explanation.para: The last statement in the dialogue is the librarian's instruction on how the student can print the article (A); therefore, you can infer that the student plans to use the printer. None of the other three choices are mentioned at the end of the conversation, so there is no evidence from which you can draw an inference.

question-stem.para: What is the talk mainly about?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: When manuscript copying was replaced by music printing
How text printing led to the development of, music printing
Why printed music is as elegant and beautiful as manuscripts
Who bought printed music in the sixteenth century

explanation.para: The professor begins his lecture by stating that the topic of the lecture is the beginnings of the music printing industry, which would lead to its development (B). The other options are details, not main ideas.

question-stem.para: Why does the professor suggest that moveable type printing took a long time to become common?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Very few people understood how the printing presses worked.
Scribes united to protect their manuscript copying business.
Early printers had a limited production capacity.
People preferred handwritten books with colored illustrations.

explanation.para: The professor states that the early printing presses had a hard time keeping up with the demands, which indicates that the production capacity was limiting their requests. The professor said that there weren't enough people to copy books, not print them (A), and there is no mention of the scribes' uniting to protect the copying business (B). The fact that some people prefer handwritten books is not relevant (D).

question-stem.para: What does the professor mean when he says:

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: That he is returning to his original topic after an interruption
That he wants to find out what the students know
That he is summarizing the argument so far
That he is unsure what is being asked

explanation.para: "So ... what about the music?" means that the professor wants to explore the earlier topic of music further (A). This is a rhetorical question; therefore, he is not trying to discover (find out) or elicit his students' responses (B). So here does not mean therefore or to summarize (C). The professor's tone is confident, rather than unsure of his topic (D).

question-stem.para: According to the discussion, which of the following problems slowed down the rise of music printing?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Professional musicians often could not read music.
Music is complex to print.
Printers were more interested in publishing other. material.
Local rulers refused to grant licenses for printing music.
There were not many potential customers.

explanation.para: Three key reasons for the slowing down in the rise of music printing are that it was difficult to print, printers were more interested in other areas of concentration, and there was not a great demand for music printing at that time. (A) is not a main reason, and (D) is not mentioned.

question-stem.para: What type of music did Petrucci print?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Music written for a large orchestra
Rare religious music
Music that had never been printed before
Music that was well-known

explanation.para: The professor states that Petrucci aimed to sell to people who wanted to hear familiar music; well-known is a synonym for familiar. (A) is not a given reason and Petrucci did not focus on rare religious music (B). (C) is contrary to fact.

question-stem.para: What does the professor imply about Petrucci's editions?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: They were bought by a wide variety of educated people.
They were bought only by the very rich.
They were bought mainly by professional musicians.
They were bought mostly for display purposes.

explanation.para: The professor says that Petrucci's editions were within the means, which means affordable, for gentry, merchants and artisans, so you can infer that this comprises a broad range of educated people. Theother three options contradict this fact because they are too narrowin scope.

question-stem.para: What is the talk mainly about?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: The effects of development on animal habitats
The life cycle of the Caribbean monk seal
The endangered species of the Everglades
The extinction of an aquatic mammal

explanation.para: The professor states that the talk is mainly about the extinction of a Florida mammal, the Caribbean monk seal, when he says "let's conclude our discussion of extinct Florida mammals" talking about the Caribbean monk seal. He also finishes the lecture with a general summing statement referring to the extinction of the Caribbean monk seal. The lecture does not primarily concern the life cycle of the Caribbean monk seal (B), nor does it focus generally on the endangered species of the Everglades (C), focusing rather on one. (A) is too broad.

question-stem.para: Why does one student mention the Everglades?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To introduce the topic of endangered water birds
To counter the argument that development hurts wildlife
To illustrate the kinds of habitats where monk seals are commonly found
To give an example of the dangers of uncontrolled development

explanation.para: The student uses the Everglades as an example in response to the professor's question regarding uncontrolled development (D). He is not introducing a new topic (A) even though he does bring up birds–as an example. And he is not arguing with the professor (B)in fact he is providing support for the idea that development hurts wildlife. The student's response is not connected to seals (C) in any way.

question-stem.para: What does the professor say Hawaii should do to save its seals?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Exchange more scientific data with researchers in Florida
Begin a research program to learn as much as possible about the habitat needs of monk seals
Educate the public to prevent further poaching of monk seals
Consider Florida's experience with monk seals a warning of what could happen in Hawaii

explanation.para: The professor says that Hawaiian monk seals are endangered, probably for similar reasons the Caribbean monk seals became extinct in Florida: tourism and rapid, uncontrolled development. So (D) is the correct choice. Though they are logical, (A), (B), and (C) are never mentioned as ways to save Hawaii's seals.

question-stem.para: What does the professor mean when he says:

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Marine biologists do not believe there are isolated populations of monk seals
Marine biologists hope science will find a way to restore the monk seal population.
Marine biologists feel the time has come for frank discussion about pollution in the Caribbean.
Marine biologists think isolated islands in the Caribbean offer the best chance of finding populations of monk seals.

explanation.para: The function of the idiomatic expression wishful thinking is to show that what is desired is impossible, or at least improbable, to achieve; therefore, marine biologists do not believe that they exist. Hopes, unlike wishes, indicate possibilities (B). Frank discussions (C) and offer the best chance (D) have nothing to do with the original statement.

question-stem.para: How did the monk seal get its name?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: From the way that it travels
From the time of day it is active
From the person who discovered it
From its appearance

explanation.para: In the lecture, the professor states that the monk seal got its name because it "tended to travel alone, like a monk" ( A). He adds that it had a fold of skin that resembled a monk's hood (D), which means its appearance also helped give it its name. The professor does not mention the time of day it is active (B) or the discoverer (C) as reasons for its name.

question-stem.para: What is the main point of this lecture?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Large objects from outer space occasionally hit Earth.
Meteorite impacts on Earth have killed millions of animals.
A large meteorite is likely to hit the moon sometime in the next century.
It was only in the 20th century that meteorites were discovered.

explanation.para: The professor begins by saying "today we will talk about," another way of stating the theme of the lecture, which is Near Earth Objects (N-E-Os), and their impact on the history of the Earth. The remainder of the lecture provides supporting details of this main idea. (B) is an exaggeration of fact. (C) is not the main topic, and (D) is false.

question-stem.para: Why does the professor mention the moon?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To emphasize a point about the impacts of meteorites on Mars and Jupiter
To draw attention to the possibility of meteorite impacts on Earth
To contrast it with Earth in terms of the size and shape of its craters
To demonstrate that not all asteroids have orbits between Mars and Jupiter

explanation.para: The professor mentions the large number of asteroids that have hit the moon as support for the likelihood that they have hit the Earth as well. Mars and Jupiter are not mentioned (A) and (D), and the analogy of asteroids of hitting the moon supports, not contrasts, their hitting the Earth, too (C).

question-stem.para: How does the professor present the information about N-E-Os in this lecture?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: By discussing the real and potential effects of smaller to larger objects.
By detailing the debate over their actual existence
By explaining the effects of those objects throughout history in chronological order
By comparing theories about why they hit the moon and Earth

explanation.para: The professor begins by talking about a small asteroid that hit Tungusaka and continues by discussing medium and then large sized N-E-O's. The structure of this lecture is thus best represented by (A). Although the professor does mention a debate (B), it is important in the last part of the talk. Some of the effects are potential or theoretical and order is not chronological (C). No theories for why N-E-Os hit the moon and Earth are discussed (D).

question-stem.para: What does the professor say is surprising about medium-sized asteroids?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: They are thought to hit Earth every 500,000 years.
More damage would be caused by atmospheric pollution than by their actual impact.
There are several hundred of them discovered near Earth every year.
More have hit Earth in the past million years than at any other time in Earth's history.

explanation.para: (B) is correct because the professor states that the surprising thing is that the most damage is not caused by the impact, but (is caused by) atmospheric poisoning. This is the only point of reference he makes to surprisingly, so (A), (C) and (D) are incorrect.

question-stem.para: Why was the Alvarez team's 1980 paper important?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It disproved Edmond Halley's theories.
It proved that the extinction of the dinosaurs was not caused by a comet hitting Earth.
It showed that dust from meteorite impacts could alter global weather patterns.
It produced the first firm evidence of a large-scale meteorite impact on Earth around the time the dinosaurs became extinct.

explanation.para: The professor states the famous paper by Alvarez's team was the first time hard evidence, or firm evidence, was presented as support, so (D) is correct. The Alvarez paper supported, not disproved Halley's theories, so (A) is contrary to fact. (B) is also false, and (C) is not related to the Alvarez team's paper.

question-stem.para: What does the professor mean when he says this:

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: NEO research can generate significant income for observatories.
Even the low costs of NEO research outweigh any probable benefits.
Tracking NEOs costs less and provides more benefits than most other" forms of space research .
It is worthwhile to devote resources to tracking NEOs to avoid a possible impact.

explanation.para: The professor implies that it is worthwhile to spend money (devote resources) to track NEOs in order to avoid a possible impact whenhe states that "given [considering] the potential benefits ... it's notreally that expensive" (D). (A) is incorrect because no one's incomeis mentioned by the speaker. (B) contradicts what he says, and (C)is not mentioned.

question-stem.para: What is the talk mainly about?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: The pros and cons of a current method of teaching reading
The differences between spoken and written language
The history of writing systems
The developmental problems that can affect speech

explanation.para: The professor begins the lecture by stating that today's focus will be on the differences between spoken and written language. Here, focus has the same meaning as main point, or main idea, so (B) is correct. (A) is incorrect because she does not focus only on reading, nor does she address the pros and cons (positives and negatives) of teaching it. (C) and (D) are sub-points, so they are not the main idea of the lecture.

question-stem.para: What does the professor say about reading and writing?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: They are both activities that must be learned.
They both exist in all modern cultures.
They each use parts of the brain that speech does not.
They each developed much later then most people realize.

explanation.para: The professor specifically states that "we have to learn to read or write" (A). She states only that writing emerged in highly complex cultures, not that both skills exist in all cultures (B). (C) and (D) are not mentioned during the lecture.

question-stem.para: According to the professor, what are some of the features of writing?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: It uses punctuation to aid comprehension
It uses longer and more complex sentences than spoken language.
It often reflects the era in which it was written.
It allows for information to be communicated with fewer errors than speech does.
It is often directed to an unknown audience.

explanation.para: The professor states specifically that we rely on punctuation marks to aid comprehension (A). She also states that "the sentences areoften longer and more complex" (B), and that "writing is oftendirected to an unknown audience" (E). (C) is incorrect because it isnot mentioned as a feature of writing. And (D) is incorrect becauseit does not specifically mention the type of error (that is, grammatical mistakes).

question-stem.para: Why does the professor say this:

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To emphasize that all humans are born with an ability to learn language
To indicate that genetic background plays a role in determining how well people acquire languages
To correct a commonly held misperception about language acquisition
To assure her audience that all children can be taught to read and write

explanation.para: The professor states that the language skill is innate, which means that all humans are born with it, so (A) is correct. This does not determine how well the language will be acquired, so (B) does not relate to her statement. She does not state that this contradicts a common misperception (C), and she is talking about spoken language, not reading and writing, so (D) is incorrect.

question-stem.para: Why does the professor mention ancient cultures?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To illustrate the point that languages can disappear over time
To provide background for a discussion of phonemes
To explain the relationships between ancient languages
To give examples of culture that had writing systems

explanation.para: The professor states that unlike speech, writing emerged in a few cultures, such as Sumerian, Phoenician, Egyptian, Chinese, Indus Valley and May an. It is assumed that the listener knows that these qualify as examples of ancient cultures, so (D) is correct. (A) is incorrect since the languages of some of the cultures mentioned still exist. These cultures are not mentioned as the basis of phonemes (B), and she does not discuss their interdependent relationships (C).

document.para: Test is Over
Congratulations!
You have completed the test. Click on Quit to continue.

para.emphasis: LISTENING
SECTION DIRECTIONS

document.para: In this section of the test, you will hear dialogues and academic talks, and you will be tested on your ability to understand them. You will hear each dialogue and academic top only once, and then answer some questions after each is finished. The questions ask about the main idea, supporting details, and the way the speakers use language. Answer each question based on what is stated or implied by the speakers.
While you listen, you may take notes. You can then use your notes when answering questions.
You will see the following headphones icon appear with some questions: . This icon indicates that you will hear part of the dialogue or academic talk repeated for the question.
Most questions are worth one point. Questions that are worth more than one point have a special note telling you how many total points they are worth.

You must answer every question in this section. After you answer each question click on the Next. Then click on Next in order to move on to the next question. After you click on Next you cannot return to a question.

You will be given 20 minutes to answer questions in this section. This does not include the time to listen to the dialogues and academic talks. A clock at the top of the screen will show you how much time you have remaining as you work through the section.
End of Section
This is the end of the Listening section.
Click on Next to proceed.
Once you leave this section and proceed to the next, you will NOT be able to return to it.
More time left
You still have time left for this question. You may go back to the question and review your response. click on Next to proceed.
Once you leave this question you will NOT be able to change your response for this question.

para.emphasis: READING
SECTION DIRECTIONS

document.para: In this section of the test, you will read three passages. You will be tested on your ability to understand them by answering several questions on each passage.
While you read, you may take notes. You can then use your notes when answering questions.
Most questions are worth one point. Questions that are worth more than one point have a special note telling you how many total points they are worth.

You will have 60 minutes to read the three passages and answer all questions. Some of the passages include a word or phrase that is in blue color. Click on such word or phrase to see a definition or explanation.

When you are ready to move to the next question, click on Next. In this section, it is possible to skip questions and then return to the later, as long as there is time remaining. When you want to return to previous questions that you have skipped, click on Back.

Clicking on Review in this section will take you to a review screen which shows the questions you have answered and the questions you have not answered. You are able to go directly to a new question in this section from the review screen.
When you are ready to begin the Reading section, click on Next.

para.emphasis: SPEAKING
SECTION DIRECTIONS

document.para: In this section, you will be asked to respond to a variety of tasks and topics. There are six tasks. Respond to each task as completely as you can, always speaking clearly into the microphone.
For tasks 1 and 2, you will speak about topic that are familiar to you. Your responses will be graded on your ability to speak about the topic clearly.

For tasks 3 and 4, you will be asked to read a short text. The text will then go off the screen and you will hear a talk on the same topic. For each task, you will be asked a question about what you have read and heard. You will need to use information from the text and the talk to answer the questions. Your responses will be graded on your ability to speak clearly and accurately about what you have read and heard.

For tasks 5 and 6, you will hear part of a dialogue or an academic talk. For each task, you will then answer a question about what you have heard. Your responses will be graded on your ability to speak clearly and accurately about what you have heard.
You are allowed to take notes during the reading and listening. You are allowed to use your notes to help you respond.
Listen closely to the directions for each task. You will not see the directions on screen.

For each task, you will be given a short time to prepare your response. A clock on the screen will show how much preparation time remains. After the preparation time is finished, you will hear a beep. You will be given a certain amount of time to speak. A clock will show how much speaking time remains.

para.emphasis: TEST DIRECTIONS

document.para: This test is designed to measure your ability to understand and to use English in an academic context. The test has four sections.
In the Reading section, you will read three passages and answer questions about them.
In the Listening section, you will listen to two dialogues and four talks and answer questions about them.

In the Speaking section, there are six tasks. The first two tasks ask you to speak based on your personal experience. In the other four, you will read passages and/or listen to dialogues and talks, then speak based on what you have read and/or heard.

In the Writing section, there are two tasks. In the first task, you will read a passage, listen, to a talk then write based on what you have read and heard. The second task asks you to write based on your own personal experience and ideas.
There is a 10-minute break after the Listening section.
At the beginning of each section, there are directions which explain how to answer the questions or respond to the tasks in the section.

In the Reading and Listening sections, you should work carefully but quickly. You should try to answer every question to the best of your ability. Make an educated guess on questions that you are unsure of. In the Speaking and Writing sections, each task is separately timed. In each case, you should try to respond to the task as completely as possible in the given time.
When you are ready to begin the test, click Next.
You may now change the volume. When you are finished, click on Next.

para.emphasis: WRITING
SECTION DIRECTIONS

document.para: You will need your headphones for this section.
This section is designed to measure your ability to write in English. There are two tasks.

For the first task, you will read a short text and listen to an academic talk. you will answer a question about what you have read and heard. For the second task, you will use your knowledge and experience to answer a question.
Listen to the directions for the first task.
Directions: For this task, you will have 3 minutes to read a short text. You may take notes if you wish. Then you will hear an academic talk on the same topic. You may take notes while you listen.

You will then read a question that asks about the relationship between the text and the talk. You will have 20 minutes to write a response. Using information from the text and talk, answer the question as completely as you can. You will not be asked to give your opinion. You will be able to review the text while you write. You may use your notes to help you write your response.
You should try to write 150 words or more. Your response will be graded on the quality, completeness, and accuracy of your writing. If you finish early, you may move on to the second task.

tutorialItem.para: You may now take a break.
If you do not wish to take a break, click on Next to continue.

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He needs more spending money.
He needs money to pay for school.
He wants valuable work experience.
He wants to earn credit towards graduation.

explanation.para: (B) is correct because the student had to take on (accept) extra work in order to pay for the rise in tuition, to earn more money for college, not to spend on other miscellaneous things (A). There is no mention that he wants the work experience (C) or that he will receive college credit for his work (D).

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: To indicate agreement with the student
To encourage the student to elaborate
To ask the student to repeat his question
To end the discussion with the student

explanation.para: (A) is correct because the function of the idiomatic expression "tell me about it" is to indicate agreement, so the professor supports the student's statement that the buses run late in the morning.
